CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 3, 1958, pg. 3, reads: "Arizona Simms Slain in 'Old Folks Home' - Crowd at Murder Scene - Scores of people gathered outside the tavern at 1812 Wylie Ave., called "The Old Folks Home," Monday afternoon as police probed the fatal shooting of 56-year-old Arizona Simms who was felled by three bullets from the gun of Joseph (Chef) H[C]urd alias Lou Terry. - Harris Photo." Portions of accompanying article read: "Killer Says Victim Robbed Him Earlier.  Fifty-six-year-old Arizona Simms, of 1824 Enoch St., was fatally wounded Monday afternoon by three bullets from the gun of a man who allegedly was settling a score for being robbed $17 by Simms a month earlier in same Wylie Ave. tavern, according to the police.  Joseph E. ('Chef') Curd, 65, alias Lou Terry of Heldman St., has confessed the slaying at the Hill Tavern, 1812 Wylie Ave., which is known as the 'Old Folks Home,' police say...  After the tavern shooting, Curd hurried from the scene.  He was arrested at Centre and Roberts by radio patrolmen Regis Larkins and Alfred Oglesby."
TitMainTitle: Crowd of women and men gathered in front of Hill Tavern "Old Folks Home" after fatal shooting of Arizona Simms, 1812 Wylie Avenue, Hill District
